RE-BIRTH
Now once again revolving time has brought
Those changes moulding man to something higher.
Ineffable, immutable the fire
Which courses through our veins. What seemed for naught
In Autumn, is a long-forgotten thought
Of things which were for us a hopeless mire.
How chill the world was and how bleak; desire
Unsatisfied; pleasure not even sought.
But this new glory which encircles man,
This rebirth in the new-born Spring, does seem
More hopeful than the failure of that day
To live. And then I do begin to scan
Life's pages and to think: "We do but dream.
All things are transient, soon to pass away."
I. \V. Russell.
EVENING
'Tis evening—the portals of bright day
Are gently drawn across the western sky;
Rolling in heaven, the clouds, now gold, now grey,
Bespeak the word of Nature, "Night is nigh,"
The cattle hear the voice and slowly wend
Their homeward way. The ploughman drops the plough.
The lullabys of mothers softly blend
With birds' low chirping on the leaf-hid bough.
Ah, Evening, the time for peace and rest,
Quiet repose reigns in my quiet breast,
Charmed by the soft enchantment of thine hour.
God in his wise and gracious visioning
Granted man peace and respite—Evening.
T. R. Marsh.

SINK THE NAVY

SPORTING NEWS
Lafayette's strong baseball
team, which last Saturday administered the season's first defeat to
the Black and Blue nine, and incidentally the first defeat of Hopkins spring season schedule, continued its winning ways by drubbing Georgetown 5 to 2 last Tuesday. Georgetown has always been
powerful in collegiate ,baseball,
being intercollegiate champions
several times, so that Lafayette's
win clearly- shows the Pennsyl.vanians' calibre. Yeisley, who
shut Hopkins out, was the conqueror of Georgetown.

Football has in the past and from present indications will continue to hold the predominant place in college athletic activities.
Every effort on the part of coaches and officials has been made to improve and perfect this sport. The United States Naval Academy, desirous as usual for victory in every line of sport, did not linger in the
background when their opponents adopted new methods for improvement. In order to make her men fast in football, Navy began
to play lacrosse. Further, Navy obtained the best coaches of lacrosse
in the country—Hopkins men. At this time, about 1910, lacrosse

Cambridge University crew
sprang a surprise when it recently defeated the heavier and more
experienced Oxford crew in the
seventy-sixth race of their historic classic on the Thames. Cambridge's time of 18 minutes 41
seconds was the fastest ever
rowed in an Oxford-Cambridge
race with the one exception of
Oxford's victory in 1911, when
the time was 18 minutes 29 seconds. Oxford, stroked by the
American oarsman, W. P. Mellen, hero of last year's race, was
conceded the victory beforehand
by every critic writing for the
British press.

Left Early in Week for Cumberland
and Points North

Dr. Schwarz of the Geology
Department, led two groups of
ardent fossil hunters to the wilds
of Western Maryland last Monday and Tuesday to study the peculiar geological formation in
that part of the country. The
parties each of which is composed
of about fifteen men are well
equipped with all sorts of implements for digging up the rare
beast of centuries ago. The geologists arc scheduled to travel
through the most rugged mountain region of the state and to
visit coal mines and quarries.
The members of the expedition
are expected home in two groups,
the first to arrive tonight and the
other group Saturday night.

Ell.GRAVERS

After taps was sounded, contrary to the campers custom, the
party journeyed to Annapolis. A
very brief observation of the Naval
Academy was made, followed by a
movie.
Everyone was up by 7 A. M.,
Sunday morning, the morning
watch was held, breakfast eaten,
and then came the Bible discussion
hour, the subject being "How is
one's life work discovered?" During the next hour, which was a recess, pictures were taken, boats
hired, and the surrounding inlets
and islands explored.
The assembly convtned again at
10 A. M. for a discussion of the
policies of the Religious Education,
Church Co-operation, Vocational
Guidance, Conferences and Conventions, Speakers' Bureau, Social
Service, Friendly Relations, and
New Student Work committees.
Dinner was cooked at 1 P. M.
and then the closing session was
held. The following dates were
definitely set for next year's program:
September 28—Fall retreat.
October 3—Freshman reception.
October 7—Frosh Fellowship dinner.
October 10 — Inter-church reception.
October 11—Foreign students' reception.
October 12—"Go to Church Sunday."
October 14—Council dinner for
promotion of membership.
November 4—First Fellowship dinner.
Nov. 26—International Thanksgiving dinner.
December 2—Second Fellowship
dinner.
A check-up of the members who
are going to the Silver Bay Conference was held. Anyone desiring to go should see Maurice Skinner, who is heading the delegation
this year.
After a final talk by Julian Price
on "Our Opportunity," the conference adjourned, and the return
Journey to Baltimore was begun.

Harnessing
Niagara Falls
for the
First Time

What Engineering
Owes to Faith
HE pioneer harnessing of Niagara Falls
in 1892, like all great engineering feats,
was the result of the co-operation of many
able and constructive minds. There were no
"older engineers" on this work, with younger
assistants, as is now common, because there
were no"older"engineers then. All ofthem were
young men in a young business, optimistic,
enthusiastic and willing to take long chances.

T

The original Niagara installation represented progress based largely on faith because there were many
features of construction proposed at that time which
Westinghouse Engineers refused to accept, and which
time has shown to be utterly impracticable.
Thus, in effecting a compromise, the three fundamental features of heating, insulation and regulation
of the 25-cycle machines as built, were vastly different
from the original designs. Time verified their judgment, the ten original generators operating successfully for more than a quarter of a century.
Looking back, it is gratifying that those young men
served engineering so courageously, because truly it
was an undertaking that taxed their faith to the limit.

RE-BIRTH
Now once again revolving time has brought
Those changes moulding man to something higher.
Ineffable, immutable the fire
Which courses through our veins. What seemed for naught
In Autumn, is a long-forgotten thought
Of things which were for us a hopeless mire.
How chill the world was and how bleak; desire
Unsatisfied; pleasure not even sought.
But this new glory which encircles man,
This rebirth in the new-born Spring, does seem
More hopeful than the failure of that day
To live. And then I do begin to scan
Life's pages and to think: "We do but dream.
All things are transient, soon to pass away."
I. \V. Russell.
EVENING
'Tis evening—the portals of bright day
Are gently drawn across the western sky;
Rolling in heaven, the clouds, now gold, now grey,
Bespeak the word of Nature, "Night is nigh,"
The cattle hear the voice and slowly wend
Their homeward way. The ploughman drops the plough.
The lullabys of mothers softly blend
With birds' low chirping on the leaf-hid bough.
Ah, Evening, the time for peace and rest,
Quiet repose reigns in my quiet breast,
Charmed by the soft enchantment of thine hour.
God in his wise and gracious visioning
Granted man peace and respite—Evening.
T. R. Marsh.

Left Early in Week for Cumberland
and Points North

Dr. Schwarz of the Geology
Department, led two groups of
ardent fossil hunters to the wilds
of Western Maryland last Monday and Tuesday to study the peculiar geological formation in
that part of the country. The
parties each of which is composed
of about fifteen men are well
equipped with all sorts of implements for digging up the rare
beast of centuries ago. The geologists arc scheduled to travel
through the most rugged mountain region of the state and to
visit coal mines and quarries.
The members of the expedition
are expected home in two groups,
the first to arrive tonight and the
other group Saturday night.

Harnessing
Niagara Falls
for the
First Time

What Engineering
Owes to Faith
HE pioneer harnessing of Niagara Falls
in 1892, like all great engineering feats,
was the result of the co-operation of many
able and constructive minds. There were no
"older engineers" on this work, with younger
assistants, as is now common, because there
were no"older"engineers then. All ofthem were
young men in a young business, optimistic,
enthusiastic and willing to take long chances.

T

The original Niagara installation represented progress based largely on faith because there were many
features of construction proposed at that time which
Westinghouse Engineers refused to accept, and which
time has shown to be utterly impracticable.
Thus, in effecting a compromise, the three fundamental features of heating, insulation and regulation
of the 25-cycle machines as built, were vastly different
from the original designs. Time verified their judgment, the ten original generators operating successfully for more than a quarter of a century.
Looking back, it is gratifying that those young men
served engineering so courageously, because truly it
was an undertaking that taxed their faith to the limit.
